title: Martin Kemp reveals his wedding cake was made of cannabis | Daily Mail Online
text: Share 17 shares The singer explained to The Sun : 'There was a man and woman at the top (of the wedding cake) and it was traditional but somebody else had made it… the whole thing was made of dope. 'The whole thing was a space cake. People were walking around my house off their faces.' Love doesn't fade: The ex-EastEnders star and his Pepsi & Shirley singer wife now have two children; Harley Moon, 26, and Roman, 23 The bassist said his friends and family came back for more, even after realising it was more than a traditional fruit cake. He added: 'But I'll tell you something, it was the only cake where we had adults queuing up to take a bit home.' One wedding guest was pop icon George Michael, who introduced the pair when Shirlie was his Wham! backing singer. In the limelight: One wedding guest was pop icon George Michael, who introduced the pair when Shirlie was his Wham! backing singer The Kemps remained close to the London-based megastar throughout his tough times and he was godfather to both of their children. They were so close that they were supposed to spend Boxing Day last year with the singer. The ex-EastEnders star and Pepsi & Shirley star have two children, Harley Moon, 26, and Roman, 23. They who are now thought to have been left a share of George Michael's estimated £100million estate. Martin said he was devastated at his friend's death. He wrote on Twitter: 'My whole family and I are devastated at the loss of our beautiful friend Yog! We will miss him so much! We are all heartbroken!' In the biz: Martin's son Roman (above) also paid tribute to his godfather and is expected to receive part of his £100m tribute His son Roman also paid tribute, adding: 'The man who toured the world with my mum; her best friend. 'The man who introduced my parents; who forced my mum to call my dad. The man that took me and Harley around the world; just to see us smile. The man we all love. We love you Yog.' The singer, who is attempting to find five men to play boy band members in a musical production based on Take That's music on the BBC show, said he and Shirlie do not go out of their way for Valentine's Day. But he made the romantic admission that he fell in love with Shirlie, 54, at first sight after spotting her as a with Wham! on Top of the Pops in 1982. He has said he believes the key to a happy and long lasting marriage is true friendship, not romantic gestures.
